results.title: U.N. Accuses Israel of Killing 15 Rescue Workers in Gaza
results.abstract: The United Nations said Israeli forces killed the people as they were trying to aid injured civilians, then buried them in a mass grave. Israel said nine of the 15 dead were Palestinian militants.
results.byline: By Vivian Yee and Farnaz Fassihi
org_facet: International Committee of the Red Cross
International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies

multimedia.caption: The funeral for people who were killed in Gaza last month, marked by the logo of the Palestinian Red Crescent aid group in Khan Younis, on Monday.
The funeral for people who were killed in Gaza last month, marked by the logo of the Palestinian Red Crescent aid group in Khan Younis, on Monday.
The funeral for people who were killed in Gaza last month, marked by the logo of the Palestinian Red Crescent aid group in Khan Younis, on Monday.

results.title: A Family Business Empire, and a Culture of ‘Keeping Your Mouth Shut’
results.abstract: The Irving family businesses dominate Saint John, New Brunswick. They are a major employer, but residents say those jobs have come with a steep cost.
results.byline: By Chris Donovan and Ian Austen

results.title: France Debates Adding a Missing Word to Its Rape Law: Consent
results.abstract: After dozens of men were convicted of raping a drugged Gisèle Pelicot, lawmakers moved to require that consent be given for sex to be considered consensual.

multimedia.caption: Pressure to change France’s rape law increased after the Pelicot trial. One poster showing her image says: “Survivors, fighters, together.”
multimedia.copyright: Amaury Cornu/Hans Lucas, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

results.title: These Militias Refuse to Join Syria’s New Army
results.abstract: The militias that control the Druse religious minority’s heartland in southwestern Syria have resisted the new government’s attempts to bring all armed groups under its control.
results.byline: By Christina Goldbaum, Reham Mourshed and David Guttenfelder

results.title: Netanyahu Drops Nominee for Spy Chief After Backlash
results.abstract: Eli Sharvit was a controversial choice after Israel’s prime minister fired his predecessor. Revelations that he wrote a column criticizing President Trump may have helped sink his chances.

multimedia.caption: Eli Sharvit, a former commander of Israel’s navy, is being passed over for the country’s top intelligence job.
Eli Sharvit, a former commander of Israel’s navy, is being passed over for the country’s top intelligence job.
Eli Sharvit, a former commander of Israel’s navy, is being passed over for the country’s top intelligence job.

results.title: A Prison Death Highlights an L.G.B.T.Q. Crackdown in Russia
results.abstract: The Russian government has unleashed a wave of repression against L.G.B.T.Q. people, with the police raiding gay night clubs and investigators targeting people they suspect of being gay.
results.byline: By Nataliya Vasilyeva and Alina Lobzina

multimedia.caption: Andrei Kotov, right, at a hearing at Golovinsky District Court in Moscow in December, in a photo released by Russian state media.
Andrei Kotov, right, at a hearing at Golovinsky District Court in Moscow in December, in a photo released by Russian state media.
Andrei Kotov, right, at a hearing at Golovinsky District Court in Moscow in December, in a photo released by Russian state media.

results.title: ‘I Am Disgusted’: Le Pen Voters Voice Outrage Over Her Conviction
results.abstract: National Rally supporters say the court decision punishing France’s far-right leader for embezzlement will ultimately redound in her favor.

multimedia.caption: Some of Marine Le Pen’s constituents watch her responding to her conviction for embezzlement, in Café de la Paix, Hénin-Beaumont, France on Monday.

results.title: A Symbol of a City’s Rapid Growth Comes Crashing Down
results.abstract: The collapse of the Sky Villa complex in the Myanmar city of Mandalay buried an unknown number of people amid the earthquake on Friday that killed more than 2,700.

results.title: Why Italy Made It Harder to Become Italian
results.abstract: The government says it tightened citizenship rules because of a deluge of applications from the descendants of emigrants who only coveted an Italian passport.

multimedia.caption: Until last week, anyone who had an Italian ancestor who was alive after the country was formed in 1861 could seek citizenship.

results.title: The U.K. Government Wouldn’t Ban Phones in Schools. These Parents Stepped Up.
results.abstract: In Britain, amid growing evidence of harm to young people from extreme content online, a “Smartphone Free Childhood” campaign is going viral.

multimedia.caption: Daisy Greenwell, right, and her husband, Joe Ryrie, center, in their home office in Suffolk, England, this month. They work with a small staff, including Nancy Waters, an operations manager, to run the Smartphone Free Childhood campaign.

results.title: Pope Francis’ Health Continues to Improve, Vatican Says
results.abstract: A little over a week after returning to the Vatican guesthouse to convalesce, the pope was showing gradual improvements in his movements and speech.

multimedia.caption: Pope Francis made a brief public appearance last month, greeting well-wishers from a hospital balcony, before returning to the Vatican.

results.title: Iceland Volcano Eruption Threatens Town
results.abstract: The eruption began near Grindavik, a small town long threatened by volcanic disruptions, and prompted the closure of a popular tourist destination.
results.byline: By Amelia Nierenberg and Egill Bjarnason

results.title: China Holds Military Exercises Around Taiwan in Fresh Warning
results.abstract: The drills came after Taiwan’s president, Lai Ching-te, announced measures to counter China’s influence and espionage. Beijing also wants to send a message to Washington, analysts said.

results.title: As Bangladesh Reinvents Itself, Islamist Hard-Liners See an Opening
results.abstract: A brewing shift toward religious conservatism has emerged from the political vacuum in this country of 175 million people.
results.byline: By Mujib Mashal and Saif Hasnat

results.title: Venezuelan Migrants Ask Supreme Court to Block Deportations
results.abstract: Lawyers for Venezuelan migrants asked the justices to keep in place a pause on President Trump’s deportation plan, calling it “completely at odds” with limited wartime authority given by Congress.

results.title: Rubio Orders U.S. Diplomats to Scour Student Visa Applicants’ Social Media
results.abstract: The order comes as President Trump expands deportation efforts, including of students who have spoken out in support of Palestinians during Israel’s war in Gaza.

multimedia.caption: Secretary of State Marco Rubio’s directive said that starting immediately, consular officers must refer certain student and exchange-visitor visa applicants to the fraud prevention unit for a mandatory social media check, according to two American officials.

results.title: SpaceX Puts Humans in Orbit Over Earth’s Poles for the First Time
results.abstract: Chun Wang, a Chinese-born crypto entrepreneur, paid an undisclosed amount for the mission. Some satellites are already in polar orbit, and researchers called it a routine flight.
results.byline: By Qasim Nauman and Isabella Kwai

results.title: Hooters Files for Bankruptcy, but Its Restaurants Will Stay Open
results.abstract: A group that includes the restaurant’s founders will buy restaurants from the private equity firm that owns many locations of the chain.
